moves.4... g6 5. f4 Qc7 6. e5: Setting up the usual Pawn formation and rendering lil' bro's intended fianchetto worse than useless...
moves.7. Nb3 cxd4 8. cxd4: Solidifying my central Pawn wedge and opening the QB file. I decide I must occupy this file with a Rook as quickly as possible.
moves.8... Bd7 9. Nh3: Adding additional protection to the supporting P at KB4.
moves.11. Rc1: I counter by seizing the open file, as intended.
moves.11... Qd8 12. Qd3 O-O 13. Nc5: With my bro threatening to win a minor exchange, I position my Knight to win one back. If now 13... NxB, 14 NxB NxN 15 QxN and we've each lost a Bishop and a Knight.
moves.13... Qa5+ 14. Kf2: My King may appear exposed, but I'm confident that I can adequately protect it with 4 pieces nearby to guard.
moves.14... Bc6: 14... QxP wins a Pawn. He overlooked it, or didn't want his Q in a position where it could easily be trapped.
moves.15. a3 Na6 16. Bd2: Getting my B out of the line of fire with a threat.
moves.16... Bb5: Anticipating 17 BxQ BxQ 18 BxB P-N3 forking and winning back the piece. However, this combination has a flaw.
moves.17. Bxa5 Bxd3 18. Bxd3 b6 19. Nxa6: The move he overlooked. Now Black ends up a piece down.
moves.19... bxa5 20. Bxf5 gxf5 21. g3: With a piece up, it's now just a matter of technique.
My brother graciously conceded rather than play out the hopeless endgame.
